title: Is Blitzcrank's kit healthy?
body: I seriously want to know public opinion on him. I mean I know he isn't OVERPOWERED but his kit design seems pretty toxic. You can't really hide behind minions when he presses W and runs around it. The grab is huge and moves fast. And it is NEVER fun to play against. (unless you are {{champion:32}} Amumu)

That's actually the original intend purpose of the grab - not to pull someone to initiate but to try and bring an escaping target back into the fight, I was told his original intention was to be a top lane bruiser (hence the AA speed buff +  E damage)

dark binding roots you for 3 seconds and can be countered by something like a scimitar if you are an adc(I build it somewhat often).  grab+knockup+silence is like.. 2 seconds? plus whatever teammates are throwing at you since you get pulled in instead of simply rooted.
Yes but dark binding leaves you where you are and, like you said, can be countered by cleanses. Blitz hook can't, and brings you into the enemy team where they blow you up before you hit the ground.

Blitz is healthy.  His kit is easy to balance and nothing particularly bad happens if he's in the meta.

Blitz is also anti-fun.  People generally hate playing against his low-risk, high-reward playstyle.

The grab is fine, I have more problem with his Overdrive. His grab alone is balance onto poisitioing by both him and you. Throw Overdrive into the mix and "lol what positioning" as he reposition for his grab faster than you can reposition to counterplay it

I personally think Blitz' design is pretty poor. 

Like, 90% of Blitz' power is contained in his grab. I'm not really a fan of kits that are set up like that (hello, Cassiopeia), because it makes the rest of their abilities feel incredibly lackluster. Almost all of Blitz' gameplay is tied into hitting or missing the grab, with the exception of his ult which he can use to stop champions like Malzahar or Kat. His E and W are not interesting abilities by themselves, because all you use your W for is to get better positioning for a grab or for running away, and your E is near useless except for knocking up grabbed targets. His E doesn't even get any benefits for leveling it except for a reduced cooldown. 

Blitzcrank also kinda has the same problem that Nidalee has. That is, you can miss like 90% of your skillshots, but it just takes one lucky hit for you to be a game changer. This applies both in lane and towards the late game, although at least during teamfights you run the risk of initiating for the enemy team by pulling the wrong person.

Debatable. He's a rather old champion, designed long before Riot had worked out the finer details on their design philosophy and their tech.  This means that his kit isn't nearly as refined as that of current champions; for example, his grab is poorly telegraphed, has a wonky hitbox, and looks pretty shody. 

He was probably meant as tanky, cc dispensing boxer robot, but in practice all he does is stay at range until he can grab & chain CC people. The guy's lockdown is pretty ridicoulus; if he lands a grab, he can immediately knock you up and then silence you while you get murderded. AP Blitzcrank can do that even on his own, with the ult blowing up squishys while having a huge-ass shield annd a ms-boost in case something gets wrong. 

He's not among the most broken, but  there's a reason most people don't like going up against blitz; he just needs to land a good hit *once* to change the game, and runs basically zero risk for it.

There's a reason Sivir is almost always picked in pro play. It's partially for her initiate, but mostly because she can actually CS in a lane against a {{champion:25}} {{champion:53}} {{champion:412}} without putting her in great danger.

And Riot must realize this, and their response is likely to be to nerf Sivir instead of the real problems in the lane.

And if you get hooked,

Mana cost? Well let's take the fact that Supports have a significantly higher  base mana regen than mages, and along with {{item:3070}} and I don't see the big deal.

Yes his kit is healthy.

1. "can't really hide behind minions when he presses W" - Then don't hide behind minions when he presses W.

2. "the grab is huge and moves fast" - Many champions are also huge, in comparison. Your support or tank could be considered a block to hide behind - the bigger  and tankier the champion, the better to hide behind.

3. I find it fun to play against, because if I make him chase me far enough and dodge his grab, he's now almost fully at my mercy with two spells on cooldown and his E out of range.

You should play Blitzcrank for at least 10 games, and if possible, play against players of various skill levels. Somewhere in those 10 games you'll find either someone who you just can't grab unless maybe you burn Flash, or you'll land your grabs and still not come out on top somehow, or you'll get counterpicked and have a serious chunk of your playstyle squashed. But also, if you win all 10 of those games, consider that you might just play Blitzcrank really well. You can then reflect on what seemed so easy to do that it was basically toxic, and ask the question "could my opponents have done something about that?" Most of the time, the answer will be "yes, they could do something", which is healthy.

1. So basically you are saying let him completely halt your CS just by running up?

I have played Blitz plenty. Its fun. So was spear-chucking Nidalee back before her rework. But its not fun to play AGAINST. 

'"yes, they could do something", which is healthy'.- Flawed logic. *All you have to do is dodge it.* If it was that simple every champion with a skillshot would be useless.

1. Isn't that what Leona does? Thresh? Braum? Alistar?

Who ever said dodging was the only option? And no, my logic is not flawed, yours is. Not every champion with a skillshot has Blitzcrank's mana issues. Not every champion with a skillshot can hit only one thing with that skillshot every 20-16 seconds. Not every champion with a skillshot has to seriously consider hitting the wrong champion with it.

While not the only solution, the simplest solution IS "just dodge it". Another great solution is, as I mentioned, walk away. You'll position Blitz and his marksman next to your minions after the chase and successful grab, which means they take damage from minions during the fight, whereas you don't. If your support is tanky, advise them to always stand in front of you while you both run back. That successful grab isn't so successful if it hits a tank and causes a 2v2 that's in your favor because only your minions respond to the aggro.

Consider that if Blitz's marksman is following then he's not farming either, so should Blitz miss his grab, you haven't actually lost anything. If Blitz's marksman isn't following him, which will happen from time to time with more passively inclined marksman players, then beat the stuffing out of Blitz until his marksman comes to the party, if they even do come to the party.

All of those are much easier to dodge. Braum isn't a problem as long as you don't get too close to your enemies creeps, Thresh telegraphs his hook to ridiculous proportions, Alistar is... weird, and Leona has to wait for her carry to follow up (and her initiate is slower and smaller). And you can outrun Leona. When Blitz presses W you can't get out of the way fast enough.

Blitz's marksman doesn't need to stop CSing until the hook actually lands, he can just kite the wave towards them and only has to miss CS to get the harass/kill. 

His Q isn't the only problem in his kit, the W is almost worse and his passive is so troll...

I have no issue with Blitz. I do not play him, and sure he has that AOE silence of an ult, but its not like you can just walk into the enemy team when they are above wood 2. He is useless without his pull as well. 

I think the issue people have with Blitz is that he has so much zoning potential. Even if the blitz is horrid you can still accidentally walk into the hook by trying to dodge it. Also hooks that don't look like they will hit you almost certainly will. I dislike hooks as a mechanic, but i can't see blitz or thresh being toxic to the game. There is counter play to hooks, its not like Fizz E or Fiora ult or other things that have item dependent counter play.

The whole 'walking behind the creeps' thing was really more about the lane than mid-late. Plus with all the waveclear most teams have creeps aren't a problem past then unless the enemy team has baron.

I will say that, as a person who tends to play less-mobile champions (Soraka, Kayle, Kog'maw, etc.) I find him one of the hardest supports to lane against. You have to be constantly aware of where he is and what the status of his grab CD is, because one grab is basically instant death.

That said, I'm not sure if I'd call it overpowered. I only play at low skill levels, and it wrecks me there, but IDK if it's that good when people are better at dodging.

I like him. Outplaying a Blitzcrank can be pretty rewarding, but it only takes getting pulled once to result in disaster. In a straight 1 on 1 scenario, it isn't that bad. But in the context of team fighting it is an extremely powerful tool. The rest of his kit is pretty functional, no glaring faults there. His only real problem is that his Q is conditionally very powerful, and it's not even that it is overpowered.

I often play Morgana when I'm a support, and baiting out his hooks before shielding myself or my adc can be really fun and challenging, since it comes down to reflexes and clever thinking.  Does he realize I'm baiting it?  If I get too close to make my self a more appealing target, I may not be able to get the shield up.  What if I'm trying to pull it and he goes for my adc instead?  What if he successfully baits my shield out then grabs me?
Or he might just grab again while your shield is on cd.

Exactly.  It comes down to skill, awareness and reflexes on both our parts, how well we track each other's cooldowns, etc.  If we win the lane, I feel that it wasn't because my kit was better or because I hard-countered him.  It was because I outplayed their support (and hopefully my adc outplayed theirs).  Conversely, if we lose, it was probably because he outplayed me.

If he's using W, and running around minions, that should be your time to punish him for trying to walk up, you and your AD should be hitting him during those moments. Or, follow his lead and walk around the minions to the other side and 2 v 1 his AD.
